articles.title: alex (@alex_s_tramp) / Posts
articles.content: Here's how the learning usually goes wrong without backpropagation: The top person (the final answer layer) makes a guess â†’ it's way off. Super simple analogy: the "wrong answer â†’ blame backward" process Forward pass (the guess) You feed the house facts into the bottom of the network. Update step Every connection (every little number/weight in the network) now gets told: "You contributed X amount to the error â†’ nudge yourself a tiny bit in the opposite direction." (This nudge = learning rate Ã— blame score) Do this thousands/millions of times on lots of examples â†’ the network gradually gets better at guessing. As soon as you stacked more layers the blame became impossible to assign efficiently â†’ deep networks were basically untrainable. Backprop gave us an efficient way to send error signals backward through many layers at once â€” usually just a few lines of code mathematically, even for huge networks with billions of parameters.
